Technical Vignette

Alexander Fischer

2021-01-25

Source: vignettes/technical_vignette.Rmd
technical_vignette.Rmd

Clustered Standard Errors and the Wild Cluster Bootstrap

Implementation

The starting point of this section are equations (56, 58 and 62) in Roodman et al. They show that once can write the numerator as (eq. 56)

\[ R(\hat{\beta}^{*} - \tilde{\beta}) = \{S_{c_{*}} [WDXAR' :* \tilde{u}] \}' v^{*}. \] The denominator can be written as (eq. 60)

\[ \sqrt{R\hat{V}R'}^{*} = \textit{colsum} \sum_{c} m_c \times J_c^{*} :* J_c^{*} \]

where

\[\begin{align} J_{c}^{*} &= K_{c}^{*} v \end{align}\]

and

\[\begin{align} K_{c}^{*} &= CT_{c, c^{*}} [WDXAR' :* \ddot{u}] - CT_{c, FE}[WDXAR'] \times CT_{c^{*}, FE} [\bar{W} * \ddot{u}]' - S_{c} [WDXAR' :* DX] \times A \times S_{c^{*}}[\ddot{u} :* WDC]' \end{align}\]

Fast inversion of p-values to compute standard errors

For univariate hypotheses, both numerator and J are linear in \(\beta_0\). We will now show this formally and explain how to use this fact to quickly invert p-values to obtain standard errors.

Note that several objects used in the computation of both numerator and J can be written as \(\ddot{u} :* A\) or \(\ddot{u} * A\), where \(A\) one of \(\{WDXAR', \bar{W}, WDC \}\) is and \(\ddot{u}\) is the residual from the constrained model \(\tilde}\) or the unconstrained model \(\hat{u}\). All derivations are shown for case 1 - \(\ddot{u} :* A\) - while the main conclusions apply to the second case as well.

First, for the WCU, it holds that

\[\begin{align} \hat{u} :* A &= (Y - X'\beta) :* A \\ &= Y :* A - X'\beta :* A \\ &= Y :* A - X'(X'X)^{-1}X Y :* A \\ &= ((1 :- P_{x}) Y) :* A \end{align}\]

For the WCR, the analogous derivation is slightly more complicated:

\[\begin{align} \tilde{u} :* A &= (Y_{r} - X_{r}'\beta_{r}) :* A \\ &= Y_{r} :* A - X_{r}'\beta_{r} :* A \\ &= Y_{r} :* A - X_{r}'(X_{r}'X_{r})^{-1}X_{r} Y_{r} :* A \\ &= Y_{r} :* A - P_{xr} Y_{r} :* A \\ \end{align}\]

Now, note that given \(Y_r = Y - X_0 r\), it follows that

\[\begin{align} \tilde{u} :* A &= Y_{r} :* A - P_{xr} Y_{r} :* A \\ &= (Y - X_{0} r) :* A - P_{xr} (Y - X_{0} r) :* A \\ &= Y :* A - X_{0} r :* A - (P_{xr} Y) :* A + P_{xr} X_{0} r :*A \\ &= Y :* A - (P_{xr} Y) :* A + P_{xr} X_{0} r :* A - X_{0} r :* A \\ &= (Y - P_{xr} Y) :* A + (P_{xr} X_{0} r - X_{0} r ) :* A \\ &= (1 :- P_{xr})Y :* A + ((P_{xr} :- 1) X_{0}) :* A * r \\ &= P + Q r \end{align}\]

where

\[ P := (1 :- P_{xr})Y \] and

\[ Q := ((P_{xr} :-1 ) X_{0}). \]

Both quantities, \(P\) and \(Q\), are explicitely computed as such in the boot_algo2 function. Q summarizes all terms that vary in \(r\), while P summarizes constant terms.

Note that in the case of the WCU, \(X_r = X\), \(P_{xr} = P_{x}\), and \(X_0\) is a vector of length N, containing zeros. As a consequence, Q is a vector of length N of zeros only.

How it works: make use of linearity of both the numerator and J

Therefore, the following quantities need to be computed:

  • \(X_r\)
  • \(P_{xr}\)
  • \(X_0\)
  • several different object for \(A\)

Ultimately, one can write \(K\) as an expression of the form

\[\begin{align} K &= (P_1 + P_2 + P_3) + (Q_1 + Q_2 + Q_3) r \end{align}\]

for the WCR, where e.g. 

\[\begin{align} CT_{c, c^{*}} [WDXAR' :* \ddot{u}] &= CT_{c, c^{*}}[WDXAR' :* P] + CT_{c, c^{*}}[WDXAR' :* Q]r \\ &= P_{1} \times Q_{1} r \end{align}\]

with \(P_1 = CT_{c, c^{*}}[WDXAR' :* P]\) and \(Q_1 = CT_{c, c^{*}}[WDXAR' :* Q]\).

For \(J\), it follows that

\[\begin{align} J = K v & = (P_1 + P_2 + P_3) v + (Q_1 + Q_2 + Q_3) v \times r \\ &= C + D \times r \end{align}\]

where \(C = (P_1 + P_2 + P_3) v\) and \(D = (Q_1 + Q_2 + Q_3) v\).

Now, \(J :* J\) can be written as

\[ J :* J = C :* C + 2 C :* D \times r + D :* D \times r^{2} \]

The numerator can be written as

\[ A + B \times r \]

It follows that for a null hypothesis \(H_0 : \beta_{k} = r\), a t-statistic can be computed as

\[ t := t(r, A, B, CC, CD, DD) \]

So, in short: for both WCR and WCU, one can simply compute A, B, C, D, CC, CD and DD once and then invert the p-value by searching over r.

Again, note that for for the WCU, things are even easier: given that \(X_0\) is a vector of zeros, it follows that in the equations above, all elements in \(Q\), \(Q1\), \(Q2\), \(Q3\), \(D\), \(CD\) and \(DD\) are zero. In consequence, for the WCU, it follows that

\[ J :* J = C :* C \] and the numerator is

\[ A \]

For the WCU, both numerator and denominator do not depend on \(r\). In consequence, no iterative search needs to be employed in calculating the confidence intervals.
